Triggering Event:
In the stark fluorescence of her lab, Dr. Amelia Hartley was running late. Again. She had stayed up half the night reviewing data, her partner's soft snores echoing from their shared bedroom like a reproach. Another sleepless night fueled by insecurity.

She rushed to the sink, scrubbing her hands with more vigor than necessary. The clock ticked down towards her team meeting. She could picture them now, assembled without her, discussing her project, her life's work. Without her.

The lab door swung open. In walked Dr. Emma Sterling, Amelia's junior by a decade and a half, but already a published author in their shared field. Amelia watched Emma's eyes scan the room, landing on the untouched coffee maker, then flicking to the clock. She knew that look. It was pity.

"Amelia," Emma started, her voice laced with concern, "we've been waiting."

The words hung there, a physical weight pressing down on Amelia's chest. She felt her cheeks flush, her hands clench into fists at her sides. This was her lab, her team, her project. But today, she was just the latecomer.

"I had to finish some data analysis," Amelia snapped, her voice echoing off the sterile walls. "Some of us don't have the luxury of publishing our work before we've even started it."

Emma's eyes widened, taken aback by the venom in Amelia's tone. But Amelia didn't care. She was tired of being the reliable one, the steady hand guiding everyone else to greatness. Today, she wanted the recognition, the accolades. She wanted to be seen.

She stormed past Emma, her lab coat billowing behind her like a cape. As she entered the meeting room, all eyes turned to her. And for once, Amelia didn't mind the attention. She was angry, insecure, but she was present. And that had to count for something.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a failure. Can't even get out of bed on time. My partner must think I'm so irresponsible. They're always on my case about something. Like, what's the point of having a partner if they're just going to criticize me all the time? 

And now I'm late again. Of course, I am. Because I'm just not good enough. Nobody expects anything from me. That's why I stay up all night, trying to prove myself. Trying to show them that I can do it. But no matter how hard I try, I always fall short.

Those two women, Emma and Rachel, they're always so perfect. Emma's got her published papers and Rachel's got her fancy degree. What do I have? A bunch of unfinished projects and a never-ending to-do list. I'm just a joke.

And now Emma's looking at me like I'm some kind of loser. Pity, right? Like I'm just a pathetic little scientist who can't even manage her own time. Well, let me tell you, I'm not pathetic. I'm just... frustrated. Yeah, that's it. Frustrated.

Why does nobody understand me? Why can't they see that I'm trying? That I'm doing everything I can to succeed? But no, instead of supporting me, they just tear me down. It's like they want me to fail.

I hate this lab. I hate these people. They're all just so... unsupportive. Unbelievable. I swear, sometimes I wonder if anyone would even notice if I just disappeared. Would anyone even care?

But no, I won't disappear. I'll keep fighting. I'll keep pushing. Because that's what winners do. Winners don't give up. And I'm a winner. I just need to prove it to them.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy, fluorescent-lit morgue, he stood over the covered body, his badge glinting under the harsh lights like a mockery. Another goddamn kid, barely out of high school, his life snuffed out in a stupid fucking robbery gone wrong. He'd seen plenty, but it never got easier.

He pulled back the sheet, revealing the boy's face - or what was left of it. His stomach churned, not from the sight, but from the thought of the kid's mom seeing this. She'd been calling him daily, begging for information, her voice raw with grief and fear. He hadn't had the heart to tell her he didn't have shit.

He felt a pang in his chest, like a vise squeezing his heart. Remorse, he guessed. It was always there, lurking just beneath the surface, gnawing at him like a fucking cancer. He'd tried to blame it on the divorce, on the years of being a human punching bag for that kid's asshole father. But it was more than that.

He slammed his fist down on the metal table, making the sheeted body jump. "Fuck!" he roared, startling the morgue attendant who'd been quietly preparing another body nearby. The guy looked at him with wide eyes, but he didn't give a shit. Let them all see what they did to him.

He stormed out of the morgue, leaving the kid and his goddamn remorse behind. But he knew it was a lie. It was always with him, gnawing away until he couldn't tell where the guilt ended and he began. And that pissed him off more than anything.
Generated Assessment:
As I walked into the dimly lit room, I couldn't help but notice the faint scent of disinfectant lingering in the air. It reminded me of my grandmother's house, where she used to make me tea after a long day at school. The smell instantly transported me back to those carefree days, when life seemed so much simpler.

But as I gazed upon the young man lying before me, I couldn't shake off the feeling that something was off. His eyes seemed sunken, his skin pale, and his hair disheveled. It was almost as if he'd been through a war, not just a robbery gone wrong. I wondered if he'd been a soldier, or perhaps a victim of some sort of brutal crime.

The detective's words echoed in my mind - "just another statistic" - but I couldn't help but feel that this young man was more than just a number. There was something about him that tugged at my heartstrings, something that made me want to reach out and hold onto him. As I turned to leave, I caught a glimpse of the mother waiting anxiously outside, her eyes red-rimmed from crying. I felt a pang of sympathy for her, but my thoughts kept drifting back to the young man, wondering what his story was, what had led him to this place.

It was as if I'd become obsessed with the smallest detail - the faint scent of disinfectant, the sunken eyes, the disheveled hair - and lost sight of the bigger picture. But I couldn't help myself; I was drawn to the mystery, the tragedy, the senseless loss of life. And as I walked out of the room, I couldn't shake off the feeling that I'd left a part of myself behind, trapped in the memories of that young man's final moments.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Sales had been down all month at the old, creaky store. Manager blamed it on me, that lazy, smug bastard. Divorce papers still fresh in my drawer, former wife's name etched like a scar in my mind. Today, he called me into his office, again. 'We need to let you go,' he said, as if I was the one who'd emptied the registers. Rage boiled inside me, hot and bitter as unsold coffee grounds. I grabbed the closest thing - a heavy, brass figurine from his desk - and hurled it at the wall behind him. It hit with a satisfying crash, leaving a dent and sending splinters of plaster raining down like confetti. 'You want to fire me?' I spat, voice shaking. 'I quit!' I stormed out, leaving the echo of shattered glass and my own angry yell ringing in my ears."
Generated Assessment:
As I sat in the manager's office, listening to the words that felt like a punch to the gut, I couldn't help but wonder what would happen next. Would they really let me go? What if I didn't get another job right away? The thought sent a shiver down my spine, but I pushed it aside, trying to focus on the conversation at hand.

But what if I did lose my job? How would I pay the bills? My ex-wife's divorce settlement wasn't enough to cover everything, and I knew I wouldn't qualify for unemployment benefits anytime soon. I tried to shake off the feeling of unease, telling myself I'd figure something out.

Perhaps I could take some courses or get certified in a new skill? That might give me a better chance at finding work elsewhere. But what if those efforts weren't enough? What if I ended up stuck in a dead-end job, just like this one?

I glanced around the office, taking in the familiar sights and sounds. The manager seemed oblivious to my distress, too caught up in his own thoughts to notice my growing anxiety. I forced a smile onto my face, trying to appear more confident than I felt.

But what if things got worse? What if I lost everything – my home, my savings, even my dignity? The thought sent a wave of panic through me, but I bit back my fear, determined to stay calm and professional.

As I left the office, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was walking into a nightmare. What if this was just the beginning of a long, dark road? Only time would tell, but for now, I could only try to prepare myself for whatever lay ahead.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of his apartment, John meticulously cleaned his service revolver. The clock ticked on, echoing in the silence like a metronome counting down to an uncertain crescendo. His hands trembled slightly, betraying the anxiety that gnawed at him.

The phone rang, shattering the stillness. It was Sarah, his ex-wife. Her voice was soft, almost timid, "John, it's Mom. She's been in an accident. They say... they say she might not make it."

John felt a vice grip his chest. His mother, the one person who had stood by him through the divorce, the one constant in his life of chaos. The anxiety morphed into terror, clawing at his insides like a wild beast. He struggled to breathe, his heart pounding like a drum in his ears.

He rushed to the hospital, sirens wailing. The sterile white halls seemed to close in around him, each step echoing with dreadful finality. In her room, his mother lay still, tubes and machines surrounding her like a grotesque crown. Her eyes fluttered open as he approached, recognition flickering briefly before fear took over.

"John," she whispered, "Promise me... promise me you'll be okay."

He stood there, paralysis gripping him. He couldn't promise anything. His anxiety was a monster he couldn't control, threatening to consume them both. But he nodded anyway, his mother's grip on his hand weakening with each passing second.

As her eyes closed again, John felt the walls closing in. The weight of his promise hung heavy around his neck like a noose. He leaned against the wall, sliding down until he was huddled on the floor, knees drawn up to his chest. His breathing came in short, shallow gasps, each inhale feeling like a battle lost. The world outside seemed to fade away, leaving him trapped in this cold, sterile room with his fear and his anxiety for company.
Generated Assessment:
As I sat in the waiting room, I couldn't help but feel a sense of foreboding wash over me. My mind kept drifting back to the conversation I'd had with Sarah earlier that day - the one where she mentioned her mother's accident. I could almost hear the words she hadn't spoken, the unspoken fears and worries that lingered beneath the surface. It was as if I knew exactly what she was thinking, what she was trying to convey without saying it outright.

The sound of the elevator doors opening caught my attention, and I turned to see Sarah walking towards me, her face etched with concern. I could sense the weight of her emotions, the desperation to find some semblance of hope in this chaotic situation. And yet, I couldn't shake off the feeling that she was holding something back, that there was more to her story than she was letting on.

As we walked to the hospital together, the silence between us grew thicker, like a palpable fog that clung to our skin. I could feel her tension, her anxiety, and I knew that she was struggling to keep it together. But what really struck me was the look of determination on her face - a look that said she would stop at nothing to ensure her mother received the best care possible.

When we finally reached the hospital room, I was struck by the sheer fragility of the situation. The machines beeping around my mother's bed seemed to pulse with a rhythmic urgency, as if they were counting down the seconds until her inevitable departure. And Sarah, standing beside me, her hand clasped tightly around mine, seemed to embody the very essence of hope itself.

But even as I gazed upon her resolute expression, I couldn't help but wonder - was she truly convinced that her mother would pull through? Or was there another story lurking beneath the surface, one that she dared not speak aloud? The uncertainty hung in the air like a challenge, daring me to confront the unknown head-on.

In that moment, I felt a deep connection to Sarah, a bond forged in the fire of shared uncertainty. We were two souls adrift in a sea of doubt, clinging to each other for support as the waves of fate crashed against our fragile vessel. And as I looked into her eyes, I knew that I understood her better than she understood herself - that I knew exactly what she was going through, what she needed to hear.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the chilled gallery, under the harsh glow of fluorescent lights, Emma stood beside her canvas, a bitter taste in her mouth. Her lover's laughter echoed from the adjacent room, where he was admiring another artist's work—a rival's, not hers. She watched him, his eyes gleaming with admiration for someone else's creation, and felt a pang of resentment.

Her brushstrokes had grown heavy, each one punctuating her growing discontent. The vibrant hues she'd once loved now seemed garish, clashing against the stark white of the canvas. She was meant to be creating magic, yet all she could produce were these insipid lines, a mockery of her usual masterpieces.

Emma glanced at the clock. They'd been here for hours, and he hadn't even spared a moment to look at her exhibit. Her stomach churned as she realized he probably wouldn't recognize any of her pieces if they passed each other on the street tomorrow. She was just another face in the crowd, another nameless artist in his eyes.

She threw down her brush, the metallic clatter echoing through the silent gallery. The bitterness welled up inside her, threatening to spill over into tears. But Emma refused to cry, not here, not now. Instead, she took a deep breath and vowed that tomorrow, she would create something truly magnificent—a masterpiece so stunning it would force him to see her, really see her.

For tonight, however, she had only bitterness and an empty canvas to keep her company.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, watching him laugh at that other girl's art, I couldn't help but think about how little he appreciated mine. It wasn't like I was expecting him to fawn all over me, but a little acknowledgement would've been nice. You know, a pat on the back, a smile, something. But no, he was too busy swooning over some stranger's work.

I mean, seriously, what's wrong with him? Doesn't he realize that my art is the real deal? That it speaks to something deeper within us all? Or am I just reading too much into it? Maybe he's just having a bad day, and his appreciation for art is just a facade.

But still, it stings. All those hours we spent together, talking about our passions, and he can't even be bothered to look at my exhibit. It's like he's trying to tell me that none of it matters, that I'm just a footnote in his life. And honestly, it feels like a kick in the gut.

I tried to shake off the feeling, telling myself it's just jealousy. But deep down, I know it's more than that. He knows exactly what I'm thinking, and he's just choosing to ignore it. After all, we've talked about this before – how he loves my art, how it inspires him. So why the sudden change of heart?

It's not like I'm asking for much. Just a little recognition, maybe a few kind words. Is that too much to ask? Apparently so, because right now, it feels like he's ignoring me altogether. And that hurts, man. It really hurts.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the bustling kitchen of "Le Cygne Noir," Chef Henri's hands trembled as he chopped onions with an uncharacteristic ferocity. His mind raced like a runaway train, careening from one thought to another, each one sharp and biting as the aromas that filled the air.

"Where is that bloody apprentice?" he snapped at no one in particular, his voice echoing off the stainless steel counters. "I asked for those herbs ten minutes ago!"

Henri's eyes darted around the kitchen, taking in the chaos of lunch service. The clatter of pots and pans seemed like an assault, each noise a accusation of his own inadequacy. He could feel it, that familiar gnawing frustration, clawing its way up from his gut, threatening to consume him.

He had been a Michelin-starred chef once, but now... now he was just Henri, the widower, struggling to keep his late wife's restaurant afloat. The weight of her memory pressed down on him like a physical force, every corner of "Le Cygne Noir" whispering her absence.

The kitchen timer screeched, jolting him back to the present. His sauce was burning. He lunged for it, but it was too late. Blackened bits floated to the surface, mocking him with their charred silence. It was just another reminder of his failure, another battle lost in this endless war against time and memory.

Henri slammed his fist down on the counter, sending utensils clattering to the floor. He couldn't keep doing this. The pressure was unbearable, the loneliness overwhelming. He felt like a ship adrift at sea, tossed about by waves of emotion he couldn't control.

He looked up, meeting the concerned gaze of his sous-chef, Marie. She had been with him since the beginning, since before... But even she couldn't understand what he was going through. How could she? No one could.

Henri took a deep breath, trying to calm himself. He had a restaurant to run, after all. A reputation to uphold. But all he wanted to do was scream, to lash out at the world that had taken everything from him and left him with nothing but this infernal frustration boiling within his chest.

But he didn't scream. He couldn't. Instead, he turned back to his stove, grabbed a clean pan, and started again, determined to salvage something, anything, from this disastrous service. Because that's all he had now: determination. And maybe, just maybe, it would be enough to keep him afloat. For today, at least.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm such a disaster. Can't even chop an onion right. My hands are shaking like crazy and I'm pretty sure I'm going to mess up the whole dish. And don't even get me started on the state of the kitchen. It's like a war zone in here. Pots and pans everywhere, clanging away like they're trying to drive me insane.

And where's that stupid apprentice? I swear, I asked for those herbs like five minutes ago. Now they're probably ruined because nobody can be bothered to follow instructions. I mean, seriously, how hard is it to chop some onions?

Marie's always saying I'm doing okay, that I'm managing, but she has no idea what it's really like. She's never lost anyone, never had to deal with the crushing weight of grief like I have. She's just so... cheerful all the time. Doesn't know the first thing about feeling like you're drowning in your own emotions.

I look around the kitchen and see all these perfectly good ingredients just sitting there, waiting to be used. But what's the point? We'll just end up serving subpar food anyway. I might as well just give up now and save everyone the trouble.

The timer goes off and my sauce is burnt to a crisp. Great. Just great. Another thing to add to the list of things I've messed up today. I slam my fist down on the counter and send utensils flying. Why bother even trying anymore? It's not like it matters.

But then I look over at Marie and see the concern etched on her face. Maybe if I just pretend everything is fine, she'll leave me alone. So I take a deep breath, put on a fake smile, and start again. Because that's what you do when you're a professional, right? You just keep on keeping on, no matter how much your heart is screaming at you to stop.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Fuck me sideways! It's bloody raining again. I swear to god, this weather's got it in for me. I wake up every fucking morning to another day of grey, like someone pissed in my coffee - which, by the way, tastes like shit too. Been a year since Harry kicked the bucket and left me with this godforsaken house that's falling apart around me. The roof leaks, the pipes are busted, and now this fucking rain is turning my garden into a swamp. I've called every damn plumber in town, but they're all too busy or too expensive. 'Oh, Mrs. Thompson,' they say, 'you should've had that looked at years ago.' Well, fuck you very much, because Harry was the one who handled all that shit, and now he's gone, and I'm left here to rot in this fucking dump. And don't even get me started on the kids at school. Little bastards think they can walk all over me now that I'm 'the old widow Thompson.' They're lucky I don't make them write 'I will not talk back to Mrs. Thompson' a thousand times each. Damn it, Harry! Why did you have to go and leave me with this fucking mess?"
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, just great. Another lovely day ruined by this ridiculous rain. I mean, seriously, what's the point of even having a calendar if we're just gonna ignore it? Every morning, I wake up expecting sunshine and blue skies, and what do I get? A never-ending cycle of grey and drizzle. It's like the universe is conspiring against me.

And don't even get me started on the state of my house. I swear, it's like the roof is laughing at me, constantly leaking and dripping water everywhere. I've tried calling those plumbers, but they're always so dismissive and condescending. Like, hello, I know I haven't maintained the place perfectly, but come on, a little bit of TLC wouldn't kill anyone. But no, they just pat me on the head and tell me I should've done it myself. Like, I'm some kind of amateur.

And the kids at school... ugh, they're just so entitled. They think they can just waltz in here and treat me like dirt because I'm "the old widow". Newsflash: I may not be as spry as I used to be, but I still have a few tricks up my sleeve. If they think they can push me around, they've got another thing coming.

It's just so frustrating, you know? I feel like I'm stuck in this rut, and nobody understands me. Even Harry, God rest his soul, would've known how to handle these situations better. He was always so level-headed and patient. I miss him so much already.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Scenario:**

In the harsh fluorescent light of the stockroom, Sarah, 46, was alone with her thoughts. Again. She'd been busting her ass at this retail gig for years now, but it still felt like a dead end. Especially tonight.

She looked down at the box in her hands, "Returns - No Receipt". A wave of nausea hit her. She knew what that meant. Some prick had swiped a fancy watch, worn it once, then returned it without batting an eye. And she'd fucking sold it to him.

Sarah's stomach churned as she remembered his smarmy grin, his smooth lies about buying it for his wife. She'd been taken in by the whole act. She was always too damn nice.

She threw the box down, sending watches scattering across the cold concrete floor. "Goddammit!" she shouted, kicking at the mess. Her heart pounded, a mix of anger and shame boiling inside her. How could she have been so stupid?

Her mind flashed back to the manager's words earlier that week, "Sarah, you're our most trusted employee. We can't have this happening again." She felt sick. They were right to be pissed. She was fucking right to be pissed at herself.

She slumped against the wall, sliding down until she hit the floor. Tears stung her eyes, but she didn't bother wiping them away. Who gives a shit? She was just Sarah, the fuck-up who can't keep her job straight.

Her phone buzzed in her pocket. A text from her daughter, Lucy. "Hey Mom, just checking in. Love you." Sarah's heart twisted. She was failing at everything - work, life, being a mother.

She picked up the box, started gathering the watches. Each one felt like a brick of failure in her hands. She had to make this right. She had to be better. For Lucy. For herself.
Generated Assessment:
I trudged into the office, already knowing what was waiting for me. My boss would be breathing down my neck, asking why I couldn't meet those sales numbers. Like I don't know how hard I've been trying.

As I clocked in, I caught a glimpse of John from HR giving me a weird look. He thinks he knows exactly what's going on in my head. Thinks I'm some kind of failure because I haven't met my targets yet. Newsflash, John: I'm doing the best I can.

My manager called me into her office, and I could tell she was going to rip me apart. But before she even said anything, I knew what was coming. "You're just not cut out for this job," she'd say. Like I'm some kind of broken toy that needs to be replaced.

I tried to focus on the meeting, but my mind kept wandering back to all the times I'd been told I wasn't good enough. The comments from coworkers, the lack of promotions... it all adds up. People think they know what's going on in my head, but really, they have no idea.

After the meeting, I ran into Emily from marketing, and she gave me a sympathetic smile. "Don't worry, we'll get through this together," she said. Like she actually understands what I'm going through. But deep down, I know she doesn't. She's just being nice.

I left the office feeling defeated, knowing that everyone else has it figured out except me. Why can't I just be more like them? More successful? More confident? It's like I'm stuck in some kind of rut, and nobody gets it.

As I walked home, I saw a post from an old friend on social media, bragging about their new promotion. I couldn't help but feel a pang of jealousy. They must know exactly what I'm thinking – that I'm a total failure. That I'll never amount to anything.

But then I thought about all the things I've accomplished, all the struggles I've overcome. Maybe I'm not as lost as everyone makes me out to be. Maybe I just need to trust myself a little more. Yeah, right. Like anyone else truly understands me.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Aw jeez, so I'm at this conference, right? Bunch of suits and ties, all talking that same old scientific jargon. You'd think they'd invented it themselves. Anyway, there's this one guy, Harold something-or-other, keeps interrupting me, 'Oh, Dr. Thompson, I've read your work on quantum entanglement, fascinating!' Like he knows what he's talking about. Then, the little weasel has the audacity to correct me in front of everyone! 'Well, actually, it's not so much a superposition as...' I mean, who the hell does this guy think he is? If I didn't have to keep up appearances, I'd've told him where he could stick his 'actuallys'. But no, I just smile and nod like a good little scientist. Because that's what we do, isn't it? We swallow our pride and take the crap from these so-called peers. You know what? Next time, Harold, next time."

As I stood amidst the sea of esteemed colleagues, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of inadequacy. The air was thick with the weight of their accomplishments, each one a testament to their unwavering dedication and unrelenting passion. Meanwhile, I found myself struggling to articulate my thoughts, my words faltering under the scrutiny of their expectant gazes.

Harold, in particular, seemed to embody the very essence of intellectual superiority. His erudite remarks and effortless command of complex concepts left me feeling like a novice, stumbling over my own feet. And yet, despite my best efforts to maintain a composed demeanor, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was somehow falling short.

It's almost as if the more accomplished individuals around me, like Harold, possess some sort of innate understanding that eludes me. Their confidence is palpable, a tangible force that makes me wonder if I'll ever be able to measure up. The thought sends a shiver down my spine, leaving me to ponder whether I'm merely not cut out for this line of work.

In moments like these, I find myself questioning my own abilities, wondering if I'm truly worthy of sharing my ideas alongside these luminaries. It's a disconcerting feeling, one that I've grown accustomed to over the years, but still manages to unsettle me nonetheless.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "You know what's really scary? When you're sitting at home, alone on a Friday night because your dating life is drier than the Sahara, and suddenly your ex-husband calls. Not that he ever calls just to chat, no, no, it's always something urgent with him. So here I am, heart pounding like I'm back in high school waiting for my crush to call, thinking, 'Oh God, what now?' Turns out his new girlfriend's cat ran away and he swears it's mine that chased it off. Me? I was busy trying not to laugh into the phone while imagining little Whiskers giving that cat a good old software engineering ass-kicking. But hey, at least it was something happening, right?"
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, seriously? He thinks I'd freak out over some stupid cat? Like, I'm not even surprised he called me out of the blue. That guy's been trying to get under my skin since we split. And now he's got the nerve to imply I'm somehow responsible for his new girlfriend's pet running off? Please.

I swear, I can already hear him gloating about how I'm still obsessed with him. Newsflash, honey: I'm not. I've moved on. But no, he's gotta go and bring up the past, making me feel like some kind of crazy ex-wife who can't let go.

And don't even get me started on the fact that he's using this as some kind of twisted game to try and get a rise out of me. Like, hello, I'm not that easy. I've got better things to do than indulge in some childish drama with him.

But honestly, it's not like I'm surprised he's doing this. He's always been a manipulative son of a bitch, and I'm not buying whatever act he's putting on now. I know exactly what he's after – and it's not the truth. It's just more ammo to fuel his ego and make himself feel superior.

So, yeah, I'm not going to fall for it. I'm not going to give him the satisfaction of getting a reaction out of me. I'll just ignore him, like I always do. Because let's face it, he's not worth my time or energy.<|eot_id|>
